comments.userDisplayName: name with held for obvious reasons
comments.commentBody: It is to bad that this war criminal did not make this decision when his term as Gov. of Texas was finished. Oh the misery the world could have been spared.

At first glance, it would appear that W is taking the high road, staying above the fray.  No political interference, fine.  But it is also obvious from recent history that retired Republican presidents of the past 30 years have seldom tried to do anything constructive, except make easy money.  They are either unwilling, incapable, or both.  "Public service" is not in the DNA of the current Republican Party, because as we all know, public service is socialism.
Leave it to a generic republican light thinker like Royfills to make light of a war criminal.

I didn't vote for President Bush in either 2000 or 2004, but I have to say he is conducting himself well as an ex President.  Perhaps he is trying to shore up the Bush name in order to prepare for Jeb's run in 2016?
This fool now says he's "done with politics". Yeah, after the crap he's ruined us with for a generation, he gets to run away and stick his head in the sand. Coward.

Of all the different groups of people that receive government benefits, veteran's benefits should be the last to be cut. These people all put their lives on the line defending this country and that's the thanks that they get? "I'm sorry, but after all your sacrifices we can't afford you anymore?" What a disgrace.

So if he's done with politics, what's he doing on C-Span?
Oh, right, Chauncey Gardener liked being on TV too.

What's new? Was he ever really engaged enough to be said to be "in politics" in the first place? Born to money that gave him the freedom to think with his gut unencumbered by experience, and the family name without which he would have had no interest for the people who rode his coat tails to the top. The last few years of his presidency he looked so out of his depth, the increasing criticism even from former supporters seemed to be getting to him. I'm sure he's glad that all is behind him now, and without the imagination or motivation to contribute in the ways of other past presidents, he can just fade away, an empty vessel surrounded by material comfort.

For a guy who spent as much time clearing brush on his ranch as he did (almost 500 days at his ranch during his Presidency) and at Camp David (another almost 500 days), it seems as if he actually retired in 2000.  Unfortunately he didn't, but this country (and several other countries) would be a lot better off right now if had actually retired then.

Michael,

None of that is known. There will be climate change, but we don't know what changes there will be or how fast they will occur. Al Gore did all kinds of damage by referring to this as "settled science". In fact, climate science is more of the most rapidly evolving fields, and very little or nothing is settled. That business about a warmer Arctic makes for colder mid-latitude winters: that may well be true, but the explanation has an ad hoc and post hoc air to it. More importantly, the fact that this theory is only now being offered shows the science is nothing like settled. So every statement must be qualified.

The effects are if anything even less certain: Just on the issue of food supply: Some places will be drier and others wetter. The growing season in higher latitudes will expand. In the US, the drier SoCal climate may move north, and the Sonoma Desert may move north from the Mexican border; the Southeast will probably be wetter. This will likely cause water shortages in California, but these can be alleviated by more efficient forms of irrigation (briefly, drip for ditch) and, if it comes to that, by cutting back on agro use. Meanwhile, the Midwest, Upper South, Northern Plains and southern Canada may well become more fertile. The net effect on North American food production is not known, not even whether it'll be positive or negative. Meanwhile, we know a good deal more about North American agro than we do about Africa, Southeast Asia or Latin America.

This is just food. Every other issue is similarly complex and shot through with unknowns. It probably pays to keep an open mind.

This is not to say that I think burning coal like there's no tomorrow is the ideal strategy. Switching to non-carbon fuels would be prudent, to say the least, but people are not going to do it if it means doubling or tripling their energy costs. I've costed out solar power installation here in California, and it's not an attractive proposition, even with all the subsidies. This is also true on the international level--think back to Copenhagen if you doubt this.

The right way to go is to make this technology effective, and then people will adopt it naturally, without having to be dragooned into it. I'd be thrilled to support that, and I'd be happy if the governing patents were in the public domain. I won't support boondoggles like the Volt, though.

"President George W. Bush says he has left politics for good and has no plans to raise money and work for Republican candidates."

11 years too late.
He should be in prison. Period.

If only he had seen the light ten years ago and gotten out of politics in 2000 and spared us from his terrible judgment, poor governing skills, poor oversight of wall street, and  two disastrous wars!

Dubya never was interested in politics per se. He was just the puppet for the Big Oil interests. He never had any sort of intellectual curiosity about issues, only being the Cheerleader-in-Chief. So his desire to leave politics fits in perfectly with all this.
We sure don't miss Bush yet!
Well, why couldn't he have spared us in, say 2004????

He was a lazy, careless president. Now he's a lazy, careless ex-president.

Well, at least he's no longer relevant.

(From my lips to God's ear.)
In other news Bernie Madoff announces he's done with finance.
He demonstrates a lot more wisdom and class than Dick Cheney---but that's not saying much.

try this, move to DC for two years and then walk into your old post office in Chicago and attempt to register to vote. When they ask you for proof of six months residence, tell them you left some stuff in the house you rented out and fully intended to return... see if they let you register to vote.
Sounds to me as though he can't be bothered.  Sort of like when he was president.
The guy should not only be done with politics he should be sitting in prison for life for crime against humanity.
His damage remains long after his decision to leave.

I think he has been taking the high road in his reluctance to speculate and discuss President Obama's performance, in light of the  fact that he was the prior one to hold the job. He should be praised for this stance.

I didn't realize Mr Bush ever had a taste for politics - or governance for that matter. I always thought his impetus was "Aw shucks dad, I can go in there and fix a couple a thangs yall left unfixed. Course I might have to start another one of those wars. But that's okay, it'll all work out - I guess".
